column2: As a Democrat sick of the Clintons who is NOT voting for Hillary in the primaries, I'd far rather have Bernie Sanders and his principles and progressivism in the White House than Hillary, but given the way the NYT is bound and darned to treat all the other candidates like jokes instead of doing their job to cover the race means it's unlikely he'll get the coverage that he deserves to make it all the way to the nominating convention.  Just because Hillary possesses ovaries doesn't insulate her from poor judgment and a lack of commitment to the leftist values that are important to me.  Symbolism is a terrible reason to vote for someone.  Being worried about the Supreme Court overturning what's left of our civil rights is a more valid reason; why doesn't the Times start asking Hillary about the importance of leftist judges who understand the checks and balances of a federalist system, and focus less on email and obvious gender characteristics?Hillary has female sex organs.  Wow.  Is this a new discovery?  No.  Get over it, move along.  Unless you're writing an expose about the pervasive sexism of the American public.  That's worth 2000 words.  That's not about Hillary, though, and would require thought to make it page-view worthy.How about-- Hillary continues to be inconsistent on the issues, and doesn't answer questions, here are examples, and here is why we are worried-- all without mentioning Bill Clinton or Hillary's gender even once? _That_would be news.
The reality is, Sanders is one of the few Senators who has the guts to say the truth.
I'll give Bernie my vote and my time although I know he's got little to no chance of getting the nomination.

Dear Gail,Great ideas, but too many jokes here. What would happen if we treated Bernie as a serious candidate? He stands for most everything I care about for this country. I just made a small donation. It reminded me of another candidate who started out on small donations, and he won! Enough cynicism. Let's go with Bernie!

I commend Senator Sanders for his personal integrity and lucidity of argument.  In this "long speech," I think he articulates the frustration and anger of many Americans regarding this issue.The article could be enhanced if the author informed us if any other Senators are working in concert with Senator Sanders, or if this 'profile in courage' is a lone effort.
We need President Sanders very badly. Please let the universe give him to us.

TPP destroys our nation' sovereignty. Who, in their right mind, thinks this is okay to give up our representative government over to multinationals ? People who think it's only about trade are dangerously naive and playing into the hands of the multinationals. Even Doctors Without Borders understand that TPP will cause necessary medical drugs to become exorbitantly too expensive for the poor. The big pharmaceutical companies will price gouge and cause generic drugs to be too costly under TPP. The big pharmaceutical's lobbyists helped write TPP...collusion and illegal comes to mind.  All the multinational lawyers and lobbyists have helped write it and were able to read it in depth...but the American people have been kept in the dark. The media has been guilty of not covering TPP in depth, reminds me of the same lousy coverage of the run up to the Iraq war by the media. The media didn't do it's job then and are failing the American people now !  There is no excuse for Obama to push TPP this hard without the American people's representation. The democrats who voted for this are traitors to the American people. Bernie Sanders stood up against TPP, he knows it will totally destroy our middle class and destroy our sovereignty. Wiithout a middle class our country will have NO DEMOCRACY and other functioning democracies have a middle class. I'm afraid that our country is slipping toward fascism where our government is totally controlled by multinational corporations. Bernie '16

Over the years the Republican party has gone from the party of dirty tricks to cheating to seeking power at any cost while constantly moving to the right, until it a party of billionaires.They have effectively destroyed democracy.  Popular will has given way to the will of billionaires. FDR defined this as fascism. The question in 2016 is whether our freedom can survive a GOP victory.Except to the extent that some are worse than the others it makes no difference who the GOP runs. Not one is qualified for office by experience  or has a vision of the future they dare disclose.  Not so with the Democrats My choice would be Sanders but his chance of election is risky and while the people like him and his program, there is a risk we cannot take that a Republican will get elected on a tidalwave of money and slander.The much slandered and highly qualified Hillary though actually to the left of Obama is the safest bet against having a billionaire controlled pigmy in the White House.  Bill Clinton who, as Republican-lite, cared about people and was extremely well liked, ran the country well, although he signed some awful Republican laws. The Republicans have changed the rules of the game and now complain that Hillary is not only playing by their rules that she is good at it. I want Warren or Sanders but Warren won’t run and Sanders will not play the game an will loose. So I’m rooting for Hillary because she is smarter than any of the Republicans and believes in democracy.

Senator Sanders' entry into the race could be extremely valuable for the country and the process-depending, of course, on how the media presents Mr. Sanders, and what the media focus becomes. Will it be the story of what's right and just in terms of opportunity for the average American and income equality? Or, will he be subtly attacked and derided as too far left, or as a socialist?In the by-line on the front page of the digital edition. the Times says he "will inject a leftist voice into the contest". Then, in the article, he is referred to as "injecting a progressive voice into the contest". So, which is it? Is he a LEFTIST (negative connotation), or is he a PROGRESSIVE VOICE? People will need to demand a well rounded, healthy debate, and fight against the media tendency to follow the leader.
